snippet: Marketers may pay to rename stadiums, place their wares in movies or even flash ads on clouds Bat-signal style, but they can no longer invade textbooks, at least in California.    Under a law enacted in August, state money may not be used to buy t...
lead_paragraph: Marketers may pay to rename stadiums, place their wares in movies or even flash ads on clouds Bat-signal style, but they can no longer invade textbooks, at least in California. Under a law enacted in August, state money may not be used to buy textbooks containing product logos or references to brand names unless the state education board finds that they are needed for educational purposes, or the products appear incidentally in photos.
abstract: California starts enforcing law preventing state funds from being used to buy textbooks that include product logos or references to brand names unless state education board finds they are needed for eduational purposes or products appear incidentally in photos (S)
